DIV1.P: The SHORTER CATECHISM Composed by the REVEREND ASSEMBLY of DIVINES At WESTMINSTER.

P.HI: With Proofs thereof out of the Scriptures.

DIV1.P: Which are either some of the former∣ly quoted places, or others gathered from their other Writings; all fitted both for Brevity & Clearness, to this their Form of Sound Words.

For the Benefit of Christians in ge∣neral, and of Youth & Children in un∣derstanding in particular; that they may with more ease acquaint them∣selves with the Truth according to the Scriptures, and with the Scriptures themselves.
Printed by B. Harris, and J. Allen, and are to be Sold at the London Coffee-House. 1691.

DIV1.HEAD: The SHORTER CATECHISM Agreed upon by the Reverend Assem∣bly of Divines at Westminster.
DIV1.P: Q. What is the chief end of man?
A. Man's chief end is to glori∣fie GodI Cor. 10. 31. Rom. 11. 36., and enjoy him for e∣verPs. 73. to the end.
Q. What rule hath God given to direct us how we may glorifie & en∣joy Him?
A. The word of God which is contained in the Scriptures of the Old and New-Testament2 Tim. 3. 17, Ephes 2. 20. , is the only way to direct us how we may glorifie and enjoy himI John 1, 3, 4..

P.HI: Q. What do the Scriptures princi∣pally teach?

DIV1.P: A. The Scriptures principally teach what man is to believe concerning God, & what duty God requireth of man2 Tim. 1. 13, & 3. 6..
Q What is GOD?
A. GOD is a SpiritJoh. 4. 24.,Exo. 3. 14., Infinite, Eternal, and Unchangeable in his Being, Wisdom, pow∣er, Holiness, Justice, Good∣ness & truth,
Q. Are there more Gods than ?
A. There is bt ONE only the living & true GODDeut. 6. 4. Jer. 10.10..
Q. How many Persons are there in the God-Head?
A. There are three Persons in the God-Head▪ the Father, the Son, & the Holy Ghost, & these▪ Three are GOD, the same in Substance, equal in power & Glory.I Joh 5. 7. Mat. 23. 19.
Q. What are the Decrees of God?
A. The Decrees of God are His eternal purpose, according to, the Counsel of his own Will, whereby for His own Glory He hath fore-ordained whatsoever comes to passEph. 1. 4, 11. Rom. 9. 2, 23.
Q. How doth God execute His de∣crees?
A. God executeth His Decrees in the Works of Creation and Providence.
Q. What is the work of Creation?
A. The work of Creation is God's Making all things of no∣thing, by the Word , in the space of all very goodGen. 1. Heb. 11.

P.HI: Q. How did God

DIV1.P: A. God created Man Male & Fe∣male, after His owne Image, in knowledg Righteousness & Holiness; with dominion over the Creatures,
Q. What are God's worksGen. 1. 2, 27, 28. Col. 3. 10. Eph. 4. 24. providence; ▪
A. God's works of Providence are His most holyPs. 143. 17., wise104. 2,4. Isa. 28, 19., and powerfulPs. 103. . preserving & govern∣ing all His Creatures, and all their Actions

P.HI: Q. What special act of Providence God exercise towards man in the tate wherein he was created?

DIV1.P: A. When God had created man▪ enred into a Covenant of life with him, upon condition of perfect Obedience, forbidding him to eat of the Tree of Knowled of good and evil upon pain of Death.Gal. 3. 12. Gen. 2.7.
Q. Did our first Parents contin in the estate wherein they were created?
A. Our first Parents being left to the freedom of their own will, the estate wherein they were by sining against Godchap. 3. 6. 7, 8, 13. Eccl. 7. 2.
Q. What is Sin?
want of conformityI Jo. 3, 4. sapn ansgression of the Law
Q. What was the sin whereby first Parents fell from the estate wherein they were created.
A. The sin whereby our first Parents fell▪ from the estate wherein they were Created was their eating of the forbidden, fruitGen. 3. 6, 12.
Q. Did all Mankind fall in A∣dams first Transgression?

A. The Covenant being made with Adam not only for himself bt for his Posterity, all mankind descending from him by ordina∣ry Generation, sinned in him & fell with him in his first Trans∣gressionchap. 2. 16, 17. Ro. 5. 12. 1 Cor. 15. 5.
Q. Into what estate did the fall bring mankind?
A. The Fall brought mankind into an estate of sin and Mise∣ry
Q. Wherein consists the Sinfulness of that estate whereinto mn fell?

A. The sinfulness of that estate whereinto man fell, consists in the guilt of Adams first sin want of original & the Corruption of his ture, which is commonly
Original Sin; together with all actual Transgressions which ceeds from itchap. . 12, 19..

P.HI: Q. What is the Misery of that e∣state whereinto man fell?

DIV1.P: A. All mankind by their fall lost Communion with GodGen. 3. 8, 10, 24., are under His Wrath and CurseEph. 2. 2, 3. Gal. 3. 10.. & o made liable to all miseries in this life, to Death it self & to the pains of Hell for everLam. 3. 93. Rom. 6. 23. Mat. 25. 41, 46.

P.HI: Q. Did God leave all Mankind to persh in the state of sin and mi∣sery?

DIV1.P: A. God having out of his meer good pleasure from eternity elected some to everlasting Life,Eph. 1. 4. did enter into a covenant of grace to deliver them out of the tate of sin and misery, and to bring them into a state of Sal∣vation by a RedeemerRom. 3. 20, 21, 22. Gal. 3. 21, 22.

P.HI: Q. Who is the Redeemer of Gods Elect?

DIV1.P:
A. The only Redeemer of Gods lect, is the Lord Jesus Christ1 Tim 2, 5, 6. who being the eternal Son of God, became manJohn . 14., & so was, continues to be God & man in distinct natures, and one
Person for everRo. 9. 5. Luk. 1. .
Q. How did Christ being the Son of God become man?

A. Christ the Son of God became man, by tking to Himself a true bodyHeb. . 14, 16, & 10. 5. & a reasonable soulMat. 6. 38., be∣ing conceived by the power of the Holy Gost in the womb of the Vir∣gin Mary, & born of herLuc. 1. 27, 31, 35, 43.Gal. 4. 4., & yet without sin.
Q. What Offices doth Christ exe∣cute as our redeemer?
A. Christ as our Redeemer exe∣cuteth the Office of a Prophet, of a Priest,Heb. 4. 15, , 26. & of a King, both in his ∣state of Humiliation & ExaltationActs 3. 21, 22. Heb, . 25.
Q. How doth Christ execute the, Office of a Prophet?
A. Christ executeth the office of a Prophet in revealing to us by His word and spirit the Will of God for our SalvationJohn 1. 18. 1 Pet. 1. 10. 11, 12. Jo. 15. 15..

P.HI: Q. How doth Christ execute the Office of a Priest?

DIV1.P: A. Christ executeth the office of a Priest in once Offering, up himself a sacrifice to sas Divine Justiceheb. 9. 14. 28. & reconcile us to God & continual for . 7. 24, 25.

P.HI: Q. How doth Christ execute the Office of a King?

DIV1.P: A. Christ executeth the Office of a King in subduing us to him selfAct. 1. 14, 15, 16., in rulingIsa. 33. 22., and defen∣ding usIsa. 32. 1, 2., and in restraining & Conquering all His and our Ene∣mies1 Cor. 15. 25. Ps. 110. through∣out.

P.HI: Q. Wherein did Christs Humila∣tion consist?

DIV1.P: A. Christ's Humilation consist∣ed in His being Born, and that in a low conditionLuc. 2. 7., made under the Lawgal. 4. 4., undergoing the mise∣ries of this lifeHeb. 12. 33. Isa. 53, 2, 3., the Wrath of GodLuc. . 44.Mat. 7. 50., and the cursed death of the CrossPhil. . 8., in being buriedCor. 15. 3. and Continuing under the po∣er of Death for a timeAct. 2. 24, 25, 26.,

P.HI: Q. Wherein consists Christs Ex∣altation?

DIV1.P: A. Christs exaltation consisteth His Rising again from the dead on the third day1 Cor. 1. 4., ending up into HeavenMat. 16.19., and in sitting at the right hand of God the FatherEph. . 10., and in com∣ing, to judge the World at the dayAct. 1. 7. 31

P.HI:
Q. How are we made partakers
of the Redemption purchased by Christ?

DIV1.P: A. We are made partakers of the Redemption purchased Christ, by the effectual Appli∣cationTit. 3. 5, 6., of it to us by his Holy SpiritJoh. 1. 12..

P.HI: Q. How doth the spirit apply to us the Redemption purchased by Christ?

DIV1.P: A. The Spirit applieth to us the Redemption purchased Eph. 2. 8, 9. Christ by working Faith in us and thereby uniting us to Christ in our effectual Callingap. 3. 17..

P.HI: Q. What is effectual Calling?

DIV1.P: A. Effectual Calling is the work of God's Spirit2 Tim. . 9., whereby, con∣vincing us of our sin & miseryAct, 2. 37. enlightning our minds in the knowledg of Christcap. 26. 8., and ∣ing, our willEzek. 36. 26., He doth persad & enable us to imbrace Jesus Christ freely offered to us in the GospelJo. 6. 44, 45.

P.HI: Q. What benefits do they that are eff∣ectually called partae of in this life ?

DIV1.P:
A. They that are effectualy , do in this life parta of Jus∣tificationRom. 8. 30. AdoptionEph. . ., ,
and the several benefits which in this life do either accom∣pany or flow from them1 Cor. 30. .

P.HI: Q. What is Justification?

DIV1.P: A. Justification is an act of God's free Grace, wherein He pardonth all our sinsEph. 1. 7., & accepteth us as righteous in His sight, only for2 Cor. 5. 21. the Righteousness of Christ im∣puted to usRom. 5. 19., and received by Faith aloneGal. 2. 16..

P.HI: Q. What is Adoption?

DIV1.P: A. Adoption is an act of God's free grace1 John 3. 1., whereby we are re∣ceived into the number, & have Right to all the priviledges of the sons of Godcap. 1. 2..

P.HI: Q. What is Sanctification?

DIV1.P: A. Sanctification is the work of God's free graceJoh. 1. 12. Rom. 8. 17., whereby we are renewed in the whole man, after the Image GodEph. , 23, 4., & are en∣abled more and more to dye unto sin, & live unto Righteousness.

P.HI: Q. What are the benefits which in this life do accompany or flow from Justifi∣cation, Adoption, & Sanctification?

DIV1.P:
A. The benefits which in this life do accompany or flow from Justification Adoption, or Sancti∣fication,
are assurance of God love, peace of concienceRom 5. 1; 2, 5., Joy in the Holy Ghostcap. 14. 17., Increase of GraceProv. 4. 18., & perseverance therein to the endI John. 5. 13..

P.HI: Q. What Benefits do Believers receive from Crst at their death.

DIV1.P: A. The souls of Believers are at their death made perfect in olinessheb. 12., and do immediately pass into gloryphil. 1. 23. Luke 2. 43., & their bodies being still united to Christ,1 Thes. 4. 14. do rest in their graves till the Re∣surrectionIsa. 57. 2..

P.HI: Q. What benefits do Belevers receive from Christ at the Resurrection?

DIV1.P: A. At the Resurrection belie∣vers being raised up to glory1 cor. 15. 43., shall be openly acknowledged & acquitted in the day of1 Cor. 1 5. Judg∣ment, and made perfectly bles∣sed in full enjoying1 John 3. 2. of God to all Eternity 1 Thes. 4. 17..

P.HI: Q. What is the duty which GOD requires of man?

DIV1.P: A. The Duty which God re∣quires of man, is Obedience to his revealed willmiah. 6. 8..

P.HI: Q. What did God at first reveal to man a the rule of his Obedience?

DIV1.P:
A The rule which God at first
revealed to man for his Obedi∣ence, was the moral LawRo. 2. 14. 15. 10. 5..

P.HI: Q. Where is the moral law sum∣marily comprehended?

DIV1.P: A. The moral law is summarily comprehended in the ten Com∣mandmentsDeut. 10. 4..
Q. What is the Summ of the Ten Commandments?

A. The Sum of the Ten Com∣mandments is, To love the Lord our God, with all our heart, with all our Soul, with all our Strength, and with all our Mind, and our neighbours as our selvesMat. 32. 37. 40..
Q: What is the preface to the ten Commandments?
A. The Preface to the Ten Commandments is in these words, I am the Lord thy God which brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of ondage.Exod. 20. 2.

P.HI: Q. What doth the Preface to the Ten Commandments teach us?

DIV1.P: A. The Preface to the ten Com∣mandments, teacheth us that be∣cause God is the Lord, and our God and Redeemer, therefore we are bound to keep all His Com∣mandmentsLuk. 1. 74, 75..
Q. Which is the first Command∣ment?
A. The first Commandment is, Thou shalt have no other Gods be∣foreExod. 20. 3. me.
Q. What is required in the first Commandment?
A. The first Commandment re∣quireth us to know & acknow∣ledg God to be the only true God, and our God1 Chr. 28▪ 9. Deut. 26. 17., & to wor∣ship & glorifie Him accordinglyMat. 4. 10. Psal. 29: 2..
Q. What is forbidden in the first Commandment?

A. The first Commandment for∣biddeth thePsal. 14. 1. denying or not Worshipping and glorifying the trueRom. 1. 20. God, as God and our GodPsal. 81 10., and the giving that Worship and glory to any other which is due to him aloneRo 1. 25, 26..
Q What are we especially taught by these words (before me) in the first Commandment?
A These words (Before me) in the first Commandment, teach us, that God who seeth all things taketh oice of, and is much displeased with the sin of having an other God.
Q. Which is the second Command∣ment?

A. The Second Commandment is Thou shan't make unto thee any gra∣ven image, or any likeness of any thing that is in Heaven above that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth; thou shalt not bow down thy self to them, nor serve them, for I the Lord thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquities of the fathers upon the Children, unto the third and fourth generation of them that hae me & shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me & keep Commandments.
Q. What is required in the Commandment?Exod: 20. 4, 5, 6.

A. The Second Commandment requireth the receiving, obser∣ving, and keeping pure and en∣tire all such Religious Worship & Ordinances; as God hath ap∣pointed in Hisdeut. 32. 46 Mat. 28. 40. Act 2. 42. Word.
Q. What is forbidden in the se∣cond Commandment?

A. The Second Commandment forbiddeth the worshipping of God by ImagesDeut 4. 15 to 20. Ex. 32. 5, 8., or any other
way not appointed in his wordDeut. 2: 32.,
Q What are the reasons annexed to the second commandment?
A: The Reasons annexed to the Second Commandment, are Gods Soveraignty over usPsal. 95. 2, 3., His Pro∣priety in uspsal. 45. 11., & the Zeal He hath to his own WorshipExod. 34. 14..
Q. Which is the third Command∣ment?
A. The Third Commandment is Thou shalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain for the Lord will not hold him that taketh Name in vain.
Q What is required in the 3d: Commandment▪
A. The third Commandment re∣quireth the reverend use of God NamesPsal. 68. 4., TitlesRev. 15. 34., AttributesMal. 1. 1, 14., OrdinancesPsal. 1 38. 1, 2, Word & WorksJohn 36▪ 24..
Q What is forbidden in the third Commandment?
A. The third Commandment forbiddeth all Prophaning or a∣busing of any thing whereby God maketh himself knownMal. .
Q. What is the Reason annexed to the third commandment?

A. The Reason annexed to
the Third Commandment is that however the Breakers of this Commandment may escape pu∣nishment from men, yet the Lord our God, will not suffer them to escape his righteous judgment1 Sam 2. 12, 17. 22. 29. Deu. 28. 58, 59..
Q Which is the fourth Command∣ment?

A. The fourth Commandment is, Remember the Sabbath day to keep it holy, six dayes shalt thou labour & o all thy work, but the Seventh Day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God, in it thou shalt not do any work; thou nor thy son, nor thy daughter, thy man-servant, nor thy maid-servant, nor thy cale, nor the stranger that is within thy gates; for in six dayes the Lord made Hea∣ven & Earth, the Sea & all that in them is, & reed the seventh day, wherefore the Lord the Sab∣bath Day hallowed it.
Q What is required in the fourth Commandment?

A. The fourth Commandment requireth the keeping holy to God such set times as He hath appointed in His Word, expres∣ly one whole Day in seven to be
a holy Sabbath to himselfDeut. 5. 12..
Q Which day of the seven hath God appointed to be the weekly Sab∣bath?

A. From the beginning of the world to the Resurrection of Christ, God appointed the se∣venthGen. 2. 3. day of the week to be the weekly Sabbath, & the first day of the week ever since to continue to the end of the world which is the Christian Sabbath1 Cor. 11. 2. Acts 20 8. 18. .

P.HI: Q. How is the Sabbath to be San∣ctified?

DIV1.P: A. The Sabbath is to be Sanct∣ an holy Resting all that even from such worldly , and Recreations, lawful on otherChapt. 16. 25. to 29.days, & the whole time in pub∣lick & private exercises of God's WorshipMat. 12. 1, to 13., except so much as is to be taken up in the works of necessity and mercyLuk. 4. 2. Isai. 26. 63. Ezek 22 26. Amos 8. 5..
Q What is forbidden in the fourth Commandment?

A The fourth Commandment forbiddeth the Omission, or care∣less performance of the Duties required, and the prophaning
the Day by IdlenessActs. 20. 7, 9., or doing that which is in it self sinfulEzek. 23 38., by unnecessary Thoughts, Words or Works about worldly Employments or RecreationsJer. 17. 24, 25, 26. Isa. 58. 13..

P.HI: Q What are the reasons annexed the fourth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A The reasons annexed to the Commandment, are God's llowing us six days of the week or our own EmploymentsExod. 28: 9., his challenging a special propriety the Seventh, His own Exam∣ple, & his blessing the Sabbath ayGen: 2 3..

P.HI: Q. Which is the fifth Command∣ment?

DIV1.P: A. The fifth Commandment is, Honour thy Father & Mother that by dayes may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee.
Q. What is required in the fifth Commandment?

A. The fifth Commandment requireth the preserving the Ho∣nour, and performing the Du∣ties belonging to every one in their several Places and s SuperioursEph. 5 21. 22, & 6. 1, 5., Inferiour Rom. 13. 1. Eph. 6. ., Rom. 12. 50.,
Q. What is forbidden in the fifth Commandment?
A. The fifth Commandment for∣biddeth the Neglecting or doing any thing against the Honour & Duty which belongeth to every one in their several places and relationsChap. 13. 7, 8. Eph. 6. 2, 3..
Q What is the reason annexed to the fifth Commandment?
A. The reason annexed to the fifth Commandment is a promise of long Life & prosperity (as fat as it shall serve for God's Glory and their own good) to all such as keep this Commandment
Q Which is the sixth Command∣ment?
A The sixth Commandment is, Thou shalt not kill.

P.HI: Q What is required in the sixth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A The sixth Commandment Requireth all lawful endeavours to preserve our own LifeEph. 5. 28, 29., & the life of othersPsal. 82. 3, 4 Joh 29. 19.
Q What is forbidden in the sixth Commandment?

A. The sixth Commandment forbiddeth the Taking away of
our own lifeActs 16. 28., or the Life of our Neighbour unjustlyGen. 9. 6., and whatsoever tendeth thereuntoProv. 24. 11, 12..

P.HI: Q. Which is the Seventh Com∣mandment?

DIV1.P: A. The seventh Commandment , Thou shalt not commit Adultery.
Q What is required in the se∣venth Commandment?
A. The seventh Commandment requireth the preservation of our ownI Thes. 4. 4. and our Neighbour's ChastityEphes. 5. 11, 12., in Heart2 Tim. 2. 22., SpeechCol. 4▪ 6., and BehaviourI Pet. 3. 2.

P.HI: Q. What is forbidden in the se∣venth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A The seventh Commandment forbiddeth all unchast Thoughts WordsEph. 5. 4., and Actionsverse 3..

P.HI: Q Which is the eighth Command∣ment?

DIV1.P: A. The eighth Commandment s, Thou shalt not Steal.

P.HI: Q. What is required in the eighth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A The eighth Commandment requireth the lawful procuring and furthering the wealth and outward estate of our selvesRom. 12. prov. 27. 23., and othersLev: 25. 35, ..

P.HI: Q. What is forbidden in the eighth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A. The eighth Commandment forbiddeth whatsoever doth, or may unjustly hinder our own1 Tim 5. 8. prov. 28. 19. or our neighbours wealth or out∣ward estatechap. 21. 6. Job 20. 19, 20..

P.HI: Q. Which is the ninth Command∣ment?

DIV1.P: A. The ninth Commandment is, Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy Neighbour.

P.HI: Q. What is required in the ninth Commandment?

DIV1.P: A The ninth Commandment, requireth the maintaining and promoting of Truth between man & manzch. 8. 26. and of our own1 pet. 3. 16. Act. 25. 0., and our Neighbour's good name3 John 2. , especially in Witness-bearingpro. 14. 5, 25..
Q What is forbidden in the ninth Commandment?
A. The ninth Commandment forbiddeth whatsoever is preju∣dicial to Truth,Rom. 3. 3., or injurious to our ownJohn 27. 5. or our Neighbour's good namePsal. 15. 3..
Q. Which is the tenth Command∣ment?

A. The tenth Commandment
is, Thou shalt not covet thy neigh∣bours house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbours wife, nor his man-ser∣vant, nor his maid-servant, nor his , nor his ass, nor any thing that thy Neighbours.
Q What is required in the tenth Commandment?
A The tenth Commandment requireth full Contentment with our own Condition,Heb. 13. 5. with a ight & charitable frame of spirit wards our Neighbour and all is hisRom. 12. 15. .
Q What is forbidden in the tenth Commandment?

A. The Tenth Commandment forbiddeth all Discontentment with our own estate1 Cor. 10. 10., envying grieving at the good of our NeighbourGal. 5. 26., & all inordinate otions and Affections to any thing that is hisCol. 3. 5..
Q. Is any man able perfectly to the Commandments of God?Ecl. 7. 20.

A. No meer man since the fall able in this life perfectly to eep the Commandments of God but daily doth break them in thoughtGen. 8. 21., WordJames 3. 8. & Deedv. 2. Joh. 19. 11. Gal. 3. Mat. 25. 41.,
Q. Are all Transgressions of the Law equally heinous?
A. Some sins in themselves, & by reason of several aggravati∣ons are more heinous in the sight of God than others.
Q. What doth every sin deserve?
A. Every sin deserveth God's wrath and Curse, both in this Life, and that which is to come.
Q What doth God require of us that we may escape His wrath & curse due unto us for sin?

A. To escape the Wrath & Curse of God due to us for sin, God requireth of us Faith in Je∣sus Christ, Repentance unto lifeAct 20. 21., with the diligent use of all out∣ward means whereby Christ com∣municateth to us the benefits of RedemptionPro. 2. 1. 2, 3, 4..
Q What is faith in Jesus Christ?
A Faith in Jesus Christ is a Saving GraeHeb. 10. 39., whereby we recieveJohn 1. 12, and rest upon Him alone for SalvationPhil 3. 9. as He is offered to us in the GospelIsa. 22..
Q. What is Repentance unto Life?

A. Repentance unto Life is a
saving GraceAct. 11. 18., whereby a sinner of the true sense of his sinActs 2. 37., apprehension of the mercy of God in ChristJoel2. 13., doth with grie and hatred of his sin, turn from unto GodJer. 3. 18., with full purpose of, & endeavours after new O∣bediencePsal. 119. 9.
Q. What are the outward & ordi∣nary means whereby Christ communi∣ateth to us the benefits of Redempti∣on?

A. The outward & ordinary means whereby Christ communi∣ateth to us the benefits of Re∣demption, are his Ordinances, es∣pecially the Word, Sacraments & PrayerAct. . 41. 42.; all which are made ef∣fectual to the Elect for Salvation.

P.HI: Q. How is the Word made effectu∣al to Salvation?

DIV1.P: A. The Spirit of God maketh the Reading, but especially the Preaching of the Word, an ef∣fectual means of Convincing & Converting SinnersPsal. 19. 7., and of building them up in Holiness & ComfortI Thes. 1. 6., through Faith unto SalvationRom. . 1..

Q How is the word to be read &
heard that it may become effectual to Salvation?

A. That the Word may become effectual to Salvation, we must attend thereunto with diligencePro. 8. 4., preparation1. Pet. . 1, 2., and Prayer;Psal. 119. 18. receive it with FaithHeb. 4. ., and Love2 Thes 2. 10., lay it up in our HeartsPsalm 119. 11., and practise it in our livesJam. 1. 25..
Q. How do the Sacraments become effectual means to Salvation?

A. The Sacraments become ef∣fectual means of Salvation, not from any Vertue in them, or in him that doth administer them1 Cor. 7. but only by the Blessing of Christ, & the working of the Spirit in them that by Faith receive them1 Pet . 21..
Q. What is a Sacrament?

A. Sacrament is an holy Ordi∣nance instituted by Christ, where∣in by sensible signs, Christ and the benefits of the new-covenant are representedGen. 7. 10., sealed and ap∣plied to BelieversRom. . 11..
Q. Which are the Sacraments of the New-Testament?

A. The Sacraments of the New∣Testament are BaptismMark 6. 16., & the
Lords Supper1 Cor. 11. 23..
Q. What is Baptism?

A. Baptism is a Sacrament, where∣in by Washing with water in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy GhostMat. 28. 19., doth signify & seal our ingraft∣ing into Christ, & partaking of the benefits of the Covenant of GraceRom. 6. 3, 4., & our engagement to be the Lord's.

P.HI: Q. To whom is Baptism to be ad∣ministred?

DIV1.P: A. Baptism is not to be admini∣stred to any that are out of the visible Church, till they profess their Faith in Christ, and Obedi∣ence to himActs 41., but the Infants of such as are members of the visi∣ble Church are to be baptizedGen. 17. 7. Act. 2. 38, 39..
Q. What is the Lord's Supper?

A. The Lords Supper is a Sa∣crament wherein by giving and receiving Bread and Wine accor∣ding to Christ's Appointment, His Death is shewed forthLuke 22. 19. 20. and the worthy Receivers are not af∣ter a corporal and a carnal man∣ner, but by Faith made partakers of His Body and Blood, with all
His benefits, to their spiritual Norishment & Growth in Grace1 Cor. 10. 16..

P.HI: Q. What is required in the wor∣thy Receiving of the Lords Supper?

DIV1.P: A. DIV1.L: THe Scriptures of Divine Authority

L.HI: A perfect Rule for all▪ men to walk by
rom thence we learn the living God to know
And what the duty is we to him owe.

DIV1.L: Three sacred Persons in the God-head be
one Power, Substance, & Eternity.
The Father & Christ Jesus, his own Son
The Holy Ghost, & all these 3 are one
God is A most Pure Spirit Infinite

L.HI: In truth aboundant, of great power & might

DIV1.L: Most Holy Wise Just good, long Suffering,

L.HI: Of whom, thro whom, to whom is every thing

DIV1.L: He made the world, & all that is therein,
Man was made upright but soon fell by sin.
We all do from polluted Parents spring,

L.HI: And in our flesh there doth dwell no good thing

DIV1.L: None righteous are, but all of every sort
Have sin'd & of God's Glory are come short.
But God so loved us, that he did give
His only Son, that we thro' him might live.
The Son of God became the Son of Man▪
That we might be the Sons of God again▪
He's God & man, the only Mediator

L.HI: Between the Sons of Men, & their Creator.

DIV1.L: He gave himself for our Eternal good.

L.HI: And wash away our sins with his own blood.

DIV1.L: What love was this? 'twas love beyond degree.
The Offended dyes to set Offenders ree.

L.HI: It's God that Justifies, shall condemn.

DIV1.L: It's Christ that or rather rose again.
Who also sits on Gods Right-andon high.
And Interceeds for us continually.
We by one Spirit thorow him alone,
May have Access unto the Holy One.
If we believe on him that came to save,
Were sure at last Eternal Life to have.

L.HI: There's nothing that avads with God above.
But Faith in Jesus Christ which works by love
Hereby we know that we, do love the Lord,
When we do keep the precepts of his Word.
The Lord hath shew'd what he requires as good.
Deal justly, & walk humbly with your God,

DIV1.L: Serve him with fear, love him with all your might

L.HI: Speak ill of none, & give to all their right.

DIV1.L: And when you have done all you can confess
The Imperfection of your righteousness
Ascribe the praise of all the good you do.
To him that works the will & deed in you.
Keep conscience pure & void of all offence,
Blest are the dead that in the Lord do dy.
Their works do follow them assuredly.
The day is coming when the Dead shall hear.
The voice of Christ and forth with shall appear
All they to life whose works are good, and right.
All they to death that do in sin delight.
As every man hath in the body done,
so shall his Sentence at the lastpunc; day run.
The wicked shall be turned into Hell,
